questions.text: A 28-year-old male was involved in a high-speed road traffic accident. He reports severe pelvic pain and difficulty in passing urine. On examination, there is blood at the urethral meatus, and the patient complains of suprapubic tenderness. The bladder appears to be distended, and there is a high-riding prostate on a digital rectal examination. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate to confirm the suspected injury of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retrograde Urethrography (RGU)

¬†

Explanation:

  • This clinical scenario suggests a posterior urethral injury, often linked to pelvic fractures from high-speed road traffic accidents.
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) is the preferred investigation for diagnosing posterior urethral injuries.
  • It involves injecting contrast media into the urethra and taking X-rays to assess the injury's location and extent.

Urethral injury

Urethral injuries refer to damage to urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body.

Anterior vs. Posterior Urethral Injuries

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra



¬†
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra



¬†

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
¬†
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair (Option C)
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) (Option A): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation (Option B)
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate ‚Üí On IVP- Pie in sky appearance (Option D)



¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding urethral carcinoma?

choices.text: Prostatic urethral tumor is treated with laser ablation
Squamous carcinoma has a poor prognosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All are true

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

All of the statements are true

¬†

Urethral carcinoma:

¬†

Symptom

Bloody urethral discharge without infection

Prostatic urethra tumor
  • Usually associated with multifocal transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
  • Treatment- local laser ablation
  • Tendency for distant spread

Squamous Carcinoma
  • Can develop in areas of squamous metaplasia in patients with lichen sclerosus (LS)
  • Treatment- radical surgery
  • Poor prognosis

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a carcinoma penis. After discussing treatment options, he is informed that his management plan may include partial penectomy. What is the nature of his cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) T2 stage

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Partial penectomy is typically indicated for invasive penile cancers, particularly:

  • Tumors involving the glans and/or distal shaft that have invaded the corpus spongiosum or cavernosum.

  • These findings correspond to T2 stage disease as per AJCC staging.

¬†

Penile Cancer Staging (AJCC ‚Äì simplified):

Stage Description Typical Treatment
Tis Carcinoma in situ Topical therapy or laser excision
T1 Invades subepithelial connective tissue Local excision, Mohs, radiation
T2 Invades corpus spongiosum or cavernosum Partial penectomy, possibly LN eval
T3 Invades urethra or prostate Partial or total penectomy
T4 Invades other adjacent structures Total penectomy, systemic therapy

¬†

Localized tumor of glans (Option A): This could be T1 or less, potentially managed with local therapies.

Proximal penile tumor (Option B): These often require total penectomy, not partial.

T1 stage (Option C): Treated more conservatively unless high-grade or high-risk histology is present.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a noninvasive, localized squamous cell carcinoma on the glans penis. The lesion is well-demarcated and has not invaded deeper tissues. What is the TNM stage of his cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ta

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Noninvasive localized squamous cell carcinoma of the penis is classified under Ta according to TNM staging

¬†

TNM staging of penile cancer AJCC 8th edition, 2018:

¬†

Stage

Description

TX

Primary tumors cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of a primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (Penile intraepithelial neoplasia, PeIN)

Ta

Noninvasive localized squamous cell carcinoma (Option D)

T1

Tumor invades lamina propria, dermis, or connective tissue with/without lymphovascular or perineural invasion (Option A)

  • T1a: without invasion/high grade
  • T1b: with invasion/high grade

T2

Tumor invades corpus spongiosum with or without urethral invasion (Option B)

T3

Tumor invades corpora cavernosa with or without urethral invasion (Option C)

T4

Tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g., prostate, scrotum, pubic bone)

cNX

Regional nodes cannot be assessed

cN0

No palpable or visible enlarged inguinal nodes

cN1

Palpable mobile unilateral inguinal lymph node

cN2

Palpable mobile unilateral ‚â•2 inguinal lymph nodes

cN3

Palpable fixed inguinal nodal mass or pelvic lymphadenopathy (unilateral or bilateral)

cM0

No distant metastases

cM1

Distant metastases

pM1

Distant metastasis microscopically confirmed

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with a large, dry, verrucae-like growth on the penis. Biopsy confirms it as a Buschke-Lowenstein tumor. Which of the following is the wrong statement regarding the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Can spread through blood

¬†

Explanation:

Buschke-Lowenstein tumor cannot spread through blood or lymph, it is locally invasive

Buschke - Lowenstein tumor:

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis due to HPV-6 and 11
  • Large, exophytic, dry, verrucae-like growth
  • Curable malignancy
  • Locally destructive, locally invasive
  • No spread through lymphatics or blood
  • Surgical excision or partial amputation after confirmation by biopsy
  • Radiotherapy should not be given
  • Systemic interferon ùû™ therapy and Nd:YAG laser therapy is successful.

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Bowen‚Äôs disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat, and bowenoid papulosis are examples of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Premalignant penile lesions

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Premalignant penile lesions:

¬†

HPV-related lesions

Non-HPV-related lesions

1. Bowen‚Äôs disease (BD)

2. Erythroplasia of Queyrat (EQ)

3. Bowenoid papulosis (BP)

4. Giant condylomata acuminata (GCA) or Buschke‚ÄìLowenstein tumours

1. Genital lichen sclerosus et atrophicus (LS)

2. Penile cutaneous horn

3. Leukoplakia

4. Pseudoepitheliomatous, keratotic micaceous balanitis (PKMB)

¬†

¬†

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding Peyronie‚Äôs Disease?

¬†


	Is characterized by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis.
	The plaques are typically found on the ventral aspect of the penis.
	Can be associated with Dupuytren‚Äôs contracture.
	Oral medications like pentoxifylline and vitamin E are used in medical management.
	The primary treatment involves immediate surgical intervention (Nesbit Operation).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, and 4 are correct

Explanation:

¬†

Peyronie‚Äôs Disease

Definition

Characterized by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea of the penis, causing abnormal curvature during erections.

Characteristics

Plaque Location: Typically on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis.

Curvature: Resulting from plaque contraction.


¬†

Causes
  • Trauma/Injury: Repeated minor trauma to the penis.
  • Genetic Factors: Possible genetic predisposition.
  • Connective Tissue Disorders: Associated with conditions like Dupuytren‚Äôs contracture.

Associated Conditions

Galezia‚Äôs Triad:

  • Dupuytren‚Äôs Contracture: Thickening and shortening of connective tissue in fingers.
  • Retroperitoneal Fibrosis: Fibrosis in the retroperitoneal space.
  • Peyronie‚Äôs Disease

Clinical Features
  • Painful Erection
  • Erectile Dysfunction
  • Penile Curvature
  • Palpable Plaques
  • Impotence & Infertility (in severe cases)

Treatment

Observation:

  • Spontaneous Resolution: Often improves without treatment.
¬†

Medical Management:

  • Oral Medications: Pentoxifylline, colchicine, vitamin E (efficacy varies).
¬†

Surgical Intervention (If Spontaneous Resolution Does Not Occur):

  • Nesbit Operation: Placement of a non-absorbable suture opposite the plaque to correct the curvature.
  • Plication Surgery: Shortens the longer side of the penis.
  • Plaque Excision and Grafting: Removes plaque and replaces it with graft material.
  • Penile Prosthesis: For severe cases.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, including difficulty in starting urination, weak urinary stream, and frequent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, he has a history of trauma to the pelvic region. A retrograde urethrogram (RGU) reveals a stricture in the anterior urethra measuring more than 2 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

  • Urethroplasty (Surgical excision and reconstruction) is the gold standard for managing long strictures (greater than 2 cm).
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected stricture segment and reconstructing the urethra using a graft taken from the buccal mucosa.

¬†

Urethral Stricture

¬†

Definition

Abnormal narrowing of the urethra, causing partial or complete obstruction of urine flow, leading to discomfort and severe complications if untreated.

Causes

Trauma (Most common): Pelvic fractures, falls, accidents, or iatrogenic trauma from prolonged catheterization.

Infections: STIs like gonorrhea and chlamydia causing urethritis.

Medical Procedures: Urethral surgeries or radiation for pelvic cancers.

Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation from conditions like lichen sclerosus.

Investigations

Posterior Urethral Stricture: Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) to visualize the posterior urethra and bladder during voiding.

Anterior Urethral Stricture: Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU).


Emergency Evaluation: Both RGU and MCU may be used in trauma cases or acute urinary retention.

Management

Urethral Dilation: Temporary relief with dilators, often leading to recurrence. (Option A)

Optical Internal Urethrotomy (OIU): Endoscopic incision at the 12 o'clock position; effective for short bulbar strictures (<2 cm).(Option B)

Urethroplasty: Surgical excision and reconstruction; the gold standard for recurrent or complex strictures (Option C).

  • Strictures up to 2 cm: Excision with end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Strictures >2 cm: Excision and reconstruction with buccal mucosa, bladder mucosa, or penile skin.

¬†

  • Urethral Stenting (Option D) involves placing a stent in the urethra to keep it open.
    • While stenting can relieve obstruction temporarily, it is not a definitive treatment for strictures and may be associated with complications, such as infection and migration of the stent.

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text:
Assertion: Eggplant deformity is a clinical manifestation observed in penile fracture cases.
Reason: It is caused by a tear in the corpus spongiosum layer of the penis.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect
The Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect.

¬†

Explanation:

  • Eggplant deformity, which is characterized by significant swelling and bruising of the penile shaft, is indeed a clinical sign of penile fracture.
  • The deformity occurs due to a tear in the tunica albuginea, the fibrous covering of the corpora cavernosa that maintains penile rigidity.
  • The tear leads to the leakage of blood and accumulation in the surrounding tissue.

¬†

Penile Fracture (Fracture of the Shaft of the Penis)

Definition

Rupture of the tunica albuginea surrounding the corpora cavernosa, typically due to blunt trauma to an erect penis.

Clinical Features

Triad Symptoms:

  • Audible Pop or Crack: Reported during trauma.
  • Pain: Severe at the time of injury.
  • Swelling and Bruising: Noticeable swelling and discoloration.
¬†

Eggplant Deformity:

  • Characteristic appearance due to extensive swelling and hematoma, associated with significant pain and discoloration.
¬†

Blood at Urethral Meatus: Indicates possible urethral injury.

Investigations
  • Physical Examination: Initial assessment.
  • Ultrasound: Evaluates injury extent and hematomas.
  • Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU): Checks for urethral injury.

Management

Immediate Care:

  • Ice packs to reduce swelling
  • Pain management with analgesics

Surgical Intervention:

  • Repair of the ruptured tunica albuginea and any urethral injury

Postoperative Care:

  • Antibiotics to prevent infection

Complications
  • Penile Deformity: Possible curvature or fibrosis.
  • Erectile Dysfunction: Potential if injury or repair is inadequate.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle accident. On examination, he has a high-riding prostate on rectal exam, and blood is noted at the urethral meatus. He complains of difficulty in urination, and imaging reveals a pelvic fracture. Retrograde urethrography confirms a complete disruption of the posterior urethra. After initial stabilization, Which of the following is the most definitive method of management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate Surgical Repair of the Urethra

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Delayed Urethroplasty 3 months post-injury

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Delayed urethroplasty is the gold standard for definitive management of posterior urethral injuries, typically performed 3-6 months after the injury to allow inflammation to subside, Improve surgical outcomes, and reduce the risk of complications.

¬†

Management & Complications of urethral injuries

¬†

¬†

Anterior Urethral Injuries

Posterior Urethral Injuries

Management
  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterization or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications
  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Urethral stricture (most common long-term complication)
  • Urinary incontinence (due to sphincter damage)
  • Erectile dysfunction (common, due to injury near neurovascular structures)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

¬†

Immediate surgical repair¬†(Option A) is generally not recommended due to the high risk of complications like infection and stricture formation. This approach is more suitable for anterior urethral injuries.

¬†

Suprapubic catheterization¬†(Option B) is a temporary measure for diverting urine and stabilizing the patient, not a definitive treatment.

¬†

Long-term Foley catheterization¬†(Option D) is also temporary and can lead to complications; definitive surgical repair is usually required.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following is the least dilatable part of the male urethra?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urethral meatus

¬†

Explanation:

  • Urethral meatus¬†is the narrowest and least dilatable part of the entire male urethra.

  • It is often a limiting point during procedures like catheterisation or instrumentation.

The male urethra is divided into several parts:

Part of Urethra Location Dilatability
Prostatic urethra¬†(Option A¬†ruled out) Passes through prostate gland Most dilatable
Membranous urethra¬†(Option B¬†ruled out) Passes through urogenital diaphragm Least dilatable internally due to being surrounded by external sphincter
Penile (spongy) urethra (Option C ruled out) Within the corpus spongiosum of the penis Moderately dilatable
Urethral meatus External opening of urethra Least dilatable overall

  • The¬†urethral meatus¬†is the¬†narrowest part¬†of the male urethra and is the¬†least dilatable overall.

  • The¬†membranous urethra¬†is the¬†shortest and least distensible segment¬†of the urethra, but it is considered the¬†second narrowest¬†after the meatus.

¬†

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with an erection lasting over 6 hours and initial aspiration fails to resolve the condition. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intracavernosal phenylephrine injection

¬†

Explanation:

  • Intracavernosal phenylephrine, a sympathomimetic drug, is the next step after aspiration fails.
  • It helps to induce detumescence by constricting blood vessels and reducing blood flow into the penis.

Oral phosphodiesterase inhibitors¬† (Option A) are used to treat erectile dysfunction but are not appropriate for the acute management of priapism.

Observation¬†(Option B) may be appropriate in cases of non-ischemic priapism, but for ischemic priapism, active intervention is required.

Penile prosthesis placement¬†(Option D) is considered a last resort for refractory cases that do not respond to other treatments. It is not the next immediate step after aspiration failure.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with a painless erection following a penile trauma. Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of blood flow and blood gas analysis shows arterial blood characteristics. What is the most likely type of priapism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-ischaemic priapism

¬†

Explanation

Non-ischaemic priapism is characterized by a painless erection, typically following trauma, with normal or arterial blood gas characteristics which aligns with the patient's condition.

¬†

Feature

Ischemic Priapism¬†¬†(Option A)

Nonischemic Priapism

Alternative Names

Low-flow, Anoxic, Veno-occlusive.

High-flow, Arterial.

Commonality

More common

Less common

Onset

Sudden, often painful.

Gradual, less painful.

Etiology

Associated with sickle cell disease, medications (anticoagulants, antihypertensives, antidepressants, PDE5 inhibitors, intracavernous injections, alpha-blockers, methylphenidate, atomoxetine, cocaine), blood disorders (leukemia, thalassemia, multiple myeloma, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).

Often due to trauma (Perineal, pelvic, or penile trauma) or congenital arterial malformations.

Blood Flow

Decreased or absent (leading to hypoxia and acidosis)

Increased (blood is well-oxygenated)

Cavernosal Blood Gas Analysis

Dark blood, pH <7.25, PO2 <30 mmHg, PCO2 >60 mmHg.

Bright red blood, normal pH, normal PO2 and PCO2.

Doppler Ultrasonography

Minimal or no blood flow in the corpora cavernosa

Normal to increased blood flow

Urgency

Medical emergency

Not an emergency, often resolves spontaneously.

Complications

Risk of tissue damage, fibrosis and long-term erectile dysfunction.

Rarely causes permanent damage.

Treatment
  • Intracavernosal sympathomimetic drugs (e.g., phenylephrine)
  • Aspiration and irrigation.
  • Surgical shunt or penile prosthesis if refractory.
  • Observation
  • Arteriography and embolization if intervention is desired.

Prognosis

Poor if untreated within 24-48 hours, leading to irreversible erectile dysfunction.

Good, often resolves without long-term sequelae.

¬†

Neurogenic priapism (Option C), associated with spinal cord injuries, typically does not present with trauma-related symptoms and does not fit the provided clinical scenario.

Recurrent priapism (Option D)¬†refers to repeated episodes of priapism, often linked to conditions like sickle cell disease, but the patient's presentation aligns more with non-ischaemic priapism.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling of the glans penis after retracting his foreskin for catheterization. The foreskin is stuck behind the glans with visible constriction. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Manual reduction using compression methods

¬†

Explanation:

Manual reduction using compression methods is the first-line treatment for paraphimosis to reduce swelling and reposition the foreskin over the glans.

¬†

Paraphimosis

Definition

A urologic emergency where the retracted foreskin becomes trapped behind the glans, leading to potential complications like strangulation, vascular compromise and necrosis.

Etiology
  • Iatrogenic causes (e.g., catheterization, cystoscopy, routine cleaning)
  • Penile trauma
  • Self-inflicted injuries

Pathophysiology

Impaired venous and lymphatic drainage when the foreskin is retracted for an extended period leads to reduced arterial blood flow leading to ischemia and potential necrosis if untreated.

Symptoms
  • Swelling and pain in the glans and foreskin.
  • Erythema (redness)

Diagnosis

Based on history of foreskin retraction and physical examination showing the glans and a constricting band of tissue.

Treatment
  • Manual Reduction: Compression methods to reduce swelling and Osmotic agents (e.g., sugar or mannitol) to reduce edema.
  • Surgical Options: Dorsal slit procedure to relieve pressure and circumcision¬†for recurrent paraphimosis.

¬†

Circumcision (Option A )¬†is an option for recurrent paraphimosis but is not the immediate initial management in an acute case.

Topical corticosteroids (Option C)¬†are used for treating phimosis but are not effective in the acute management of paraphimosis.

Oral antibiotics (Option D)¬†may be necessary if there is an infection, but they are not the primary treatment for paraphimosis.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 5 year old boy presents with a non-retractable foreskin that has a fibrotic ring around the preputial orifice. His parents report that he experiences pain and irritation during urination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pathologic phimosis

Explanation:

¬†

Pathologic phimosis is characterized by a non-retractable foreskin with a fibrotic ring (cicatrix) and symptoms such as pain, irritation, and dysuria, which fits the patient's presentation.


¬†

Feature

Physiologic Phimosis (Option A)

Pathologic Phimosis (Option C)

Overview
  • Inability to retract the foreskin due to congenital adhesions.
  • Common in newborns and young boys
  • Resolves spontaneously over time with normal penile growth and erections.
  • Nonretractable foreskin due to scarring or fibrosis of the prepuce.
  • Less common, typically occurs in older children or adults.
  • Does not resolve spontaneously, often worsens without intervention.

Onset

Present at birth, with gradual improvement.

May develop after trauma, infection, inflammation, or forcible retraction.

Symptoms

Typically asymptomatic, occasional mild discomfort during retraction.

Pain, irritation, bleeding, dysuria, painful erections, recurrent infections.

Appearance of Prepuce

Normal appearance, foreskin adhered to glans.

Presence of fibrotic ring (cicatrix) around the preputial orifice and white scarring.

Management

No treatment needed for most cases.

Stretching exercises and topical corticosteroids if concerned.

Surgical options like preputioplasty, dilation, or circumcision if severe.

Complications

Uncommon

High risk of complications such as paraphimosis, recurrent UTIs, or balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO).

¬†

Paraphimosis¬†(Option B) occurs when a retracted foreskin cannot be returned to its normal position, leading to a constricting band around the glans, but this does not match the description of a fibrotic ring and non-retractable foreskin.

Balanitis¬†(Option D) refers to inflammation of the glans penis, usually presenting with redness, swelling, and pain, but it does not involve a non-retractable foreskin with a fibrotic ring.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A newborn male presents with urinary retention, lethargy and a distended bladder. Antenatal ultrasound showed a "keyhole sign" with a thickened bladder wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Posterior urethral valves

Explanation

Posterior urethral valves are characterized by membranous folds in the posterior urethra leading to urinary obstruction, which matches the "keyhole sign" on ultrasound and the postnatal symptoms of urinary retention and lethargy.

Posterior urethral valves

Definition

Urinary tract obstruction in male infants from membranous folds in the posterior urethra.

Complications

Chronic kidney disease, pulmonary hypoplasia from oligohydramnios.

Classification

Type I: Posterior urethral folds

Type II: Membranes at bladder neck

Type III: Round membrane at verumontanum

Etiology

Congenital, unclear embryological origin.

Pathophysiology

Increased bladder pressure ‚Üí hypertrophy, vesicoureteric reflux, renal damage

Diagnostic Tools

Ultrasound, VCUG (voiding cystourethrogram) and Renal scintigraphy.

Antenatal Diagnosis

Ultrasound: Dilated bladder ("keyhole sign"), thickened walls.

Postnatal Symptoms

Urinary retention, infections, lethargy, respiratory distress.

Management
  • Antenatal: Vesicostomy, fetal valve ablation
  • Postnatal: Stabilization, cystoscopic ablation

Prognosis

Depends on severity; long-term care needed for CKD, bladder dysfunction, recurrent UTIs.

¬†

Hypospadias (Option A)¬†involves an abnormal urethral opening and does not present with the obstructive symptoms described, such as a distended bladder and urinary retention.

Vesicoureteral reflux¬†(Option B) can occur secondary to posterior urethral valves but is not the primary condition associated with the described ultrasound findings and symptoms.

Neurogenic bladder¬†(Option D) results from nerve damage affecting bladder function, but it is not typically associated with the "keyhole sign" seen in posterior urethral valves.

¬†

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with complaints of recurrent UTI and difficulty urinating as mentioned by their parents.Upon examination, the physician notes that the urethral opening is located on the dorsal (top) aspect of the penis rather than at the tip. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epispadias

¬†

Explanation:

Epispadias

  • Congenital condition where the urethral opening is located on the dorsal (top) side of the penis (in males) or the clitoris (in females).
  • Male Epispadias: Urethral opening on the top of the penis.
  • Female Epispadias: Urethral opening located on the clitoris or along the dorsal side of the urethra.
  • Associated with bladder exstrophy.
  • Clinical features: Difficulty urinating, recurrent urinary tract infections, Undescended testis, Bifid clitoris, Widely separated labia, Urinary incontinence.
  • Treatment: Modified Cantwell-Ransley repair and Mitchell repair.
  • Epispadias repairs must deal with correction of the dorsal chordee and curvature, Dissection of the corpora and lengthening them by medial rotation, Urethral reconstruction for urination and ejaculation, Reconstruction of the glans penis.

Hypospadias (Option A):

  • Congenital condition where the urethral opening is on the underside of the penis and not on the top side of penis.

¬†

Peyronie Disease (Option B):

  • Characterized by the development of fibrous plaques in the penile tissue.
  • It affects penile shape and function but not the position of the urethral opening.

¬†

Phimosis (Option D):

  • Condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted over the glans (head) of the penis.
  • This is not related to the position of the urethral opening.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and a history of abnormal urination. Physical examination reveals an abnormal opening on the perineum instead of the tip of the penis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypospadias

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Hypospadias:

  • It is a congenital condition in which the urethral opening is located on the ventral (underside) of the penis, and in severe cases, may be found as far back as the perineum.

  • Associated with abnormal urination, spraying, or downward deflection of urine.

  • Can lead to recurrent UTIs due to poor urinary stream and stasis.

  • Often associated with chordee (ventral penile curvature).

¬†

Feature Description
Definition A congenital anomaly where the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side (underside) of the penis instead of the tip
Location of Meatus Anywhere along the ventral shaft, scrotum, or perineum (in severe cases)
Types Glanular (near glans) Coronal Penile Penoscrotal Perineal
Associated Abnormalities Chordee (ventral penile curvature) Incomplete foreskin (dorsal hood) Undescended testes (in some cases)
Clinical Features Abnormal urinary stream Spraying or dribbling of urine May be noticed during urination or circumcision Recurrent UTIs (in severe cases)
Diagnosis Clinical examination at birth Imaging (USG KUB, VCUG) if suspected associated anomalies or recurrent UTIs
Differential Diagnoses Epispadias (dorsal meatus) Exstrophy of bladder Disorders of sexual development (if associated genital ambiguity)
Management Avoid neonatal circumcision (foreskin may be needed for repair) Surgical correction ideally between 6‚Äì18 months of age
Surgical Goals Position urethral meatus at the glans tip Straighten the penis (correct chordee) Create cosmetically normal appearance
Prognosis Excellent with early surgical correction Most children have normal voiding and sexual function later in life

¬†

Epispadias (Option B) is incorrect because the urethral opening is on the dorsal (upper) surface of the penis, not the perineum. It may also present with urinary incontinence, but is not consistent with the described perineal opening.

¬†

Ectopic vesicae (Option C) is incorrect because it refers to exstrophy of the bladder, where the bladder is exposed outside the abdominal wall. It is typically diagnosed at birth and presents with visible bladder mucosa.

¬†

Phimosis (Option D) is incorrect because it refers to the inability to retract the foreskin over the glans penis. It does not cause a displaced urethral opening and is not associated with an opening on the perineum.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of steps for hypospadias repair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Degloving, orthoplasty, urethroplasty, and glanuloplasty

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Steps of Hypospadias repair

¬†

De-gloving

‚Üì

Orthoplasty

‚Üì

Urethroplasty

‚Üì

Meatoplasty

‚Üì

Glanuloplasty

‚Üì

Penoplasty

‚Üì

Scrotoplasty

¬†

  • Degloving: Removal of the penile skin to expose the underlying structures.
  • Orthoplasty: Correction of penile curvature and any associated penile shaft issues. This step involves mobilizing and repositioning the urethral plate if necessary.
  • Urethroplasty: Creation or reconstruction of the neourethra using tissue flaps or grafts to form a functional urethra.
  • Meatoplasty: Providing vascularised coverage for the urethroplasty.
  • Glanuloplasty: Reconstruction of the glans penis, focusing on creating a normal appearance and aligning the meatus.
  • Penoplasty: Reconstruction of the penile shaft to restore or enhance its normal appearance and function. This may involve skin flaps or grafts.
  • Scrotoplasty: Correction or reconstruction of the scrotum, which may be necessary if there are associated anomalies or for cosmetic reasons.

¬†

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: What is the most common type of hypospadias?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glanular hypospadias

¬†

Explanation:

¬†

Hypospadias:

  • Caused by failure of fusion of urethral folds- meatus in ventral aspect
  • Affects about 1 in 300 male live births, Most common congenital abnormality of the urethra.
  • Characterized by:Ectopic ventrally located urethral meatus, Ventral penile curvature (chordee), Incomplete dorsal hood prepuce.

¬†

Classification/Types:

  1. Glanular Hypospadias: Most common type (Option B)
  2. Coronal Hypospadias
  3. Penile Hypospadias
  4. Penoscrotal Hypospadias
  5. Perineal Hypospadias
  6. Scrotal Hypospadias
  7. Distal penile Hypospadias

Glandular, Coronal and Distal penile hypospadias account for 60-70% of cases of hypospadias.

¬†

  • Treatment usually involves tubularized incised plate urethroplasty.
  • Two-stage repair: First corrects penile curvature, second repairs urethra, Typically done before 18 months of age.
  • Circumcision should be avoided to preserve preputial skin for future repairs.
  • Failed repair can result in urethrocutaneous fistula.‚Äã‚Äã

¬†

¬†
